key_points: A federal judge blocked a Florida law designed to penalize social media companies for banning politiciansâ€™ speech.
The law was a reaction to Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube suspending former President Donald Trump's accounts after the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
U.S. District Judge Robert Hinkle ruled the law likely unconstitutional and infringing on First Amendment rights.
The technology industry challenged the law, claiming it violated online businesses' First Amendment rights.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who signed the law, plans to appeal the ruling.
The blocked law would fine social media companies up to $250,000 a day for removing accounts of statewide political candidates.
Two technology trade groups, NetChoice and the Computer and Communications Industry Association, filed a lawsuit against the law.
The law was criticized for potentially forcing the hosting of undesirable content like hate speech and disinformation.
Carl Szabo of NetChoice praised the ruling for preventing the enforcement of a politically motivated law.
Legal experts and critics argue the law is unconstitutional and a misuse of taxpayer dollars.
spokespersons: Carl Szabo (Vice President and General Counsel, NetChoice)
Eric Goldman (Law Professor, Santa Clara University)
